newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Prince no longer in power, Cambodia's Hun Sen says.
newsitem.headline: Prince no longer in power, Cambodia's Hun Sen says.

text.p: Cambodian strongman Hun Sen declared on Sunday that his rival, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, was no longer prime minister, unilaterally ousting him from their shattered coalition government.
Hun Sen spoke in a radio broadcast after a day of heavy fighting on the streets of the capital Phnom Penh between his troops and those loyal to Ranariddh, son of King Sihanouk.
Hun Sen urged breakaway dissidents from Ranariddh's FUNCINPEC party to fill the prince's post of First Prime Minister. "The government is ready to choose a new First Prime Minister," he said.
"The position of first prime minister is in FUNCINPEC's quota so let FUNCINPEC adopt a political figure," he said, adding that he did not want the post.
Fighting erupted between Hun Sen's forces and those answering to Ranariddh on Saturday and kept up through Sunday, killing at least 12 people and wounding more than 50.
The prince, whose party won a 1993 election organised by the United Nations, charged in a statement from Paris on Saturday that Hun Sen had launched a coup against him.
Cambodian radio controlled by Hun Sen later denied the accusation and said the fighting was directed against Khmer Rouge guerrilla infiltrators in the capital.
Ranariddh's exact whereabouts were not known but aides in Phnom Penh said he left the country on the eve of the fighting and was in France.
Hun Sen's forces captured FUNCINPEC party headquarters in central Phnom Penh and Ranariddh's residence in the heart of the city on Sunday.
By late in the day, Ranariddh's forces still held ground to the west of the city and their Tang Krasang military base near the airport.
A military analyst in Phnom Penh said he expected more fighting on Sunday night or on Monday when Hun Sen's forces attempted to take further FUNCINPEC positions.
Clashes in the Southeast Asian capital stopped as a curfew took effect at 8 p.m. (1300 GMT) on Sunday, though there was occasional gunfire later. The curfew lasts until 6 a.m. (2300 GMT).
Hun Sen said the situation was under control.

The two premiers had jointly headed an unstable coalition government formed after the U.N.-run election in 1993 which brought hopes of peace to the ravaged country after three decades of conflict inflamed by war in nearby Vietnam.
Last week, Hun Sen accused Ranariddh of illegally bringing Khmer Rouge defectors into Phnom Penh to bolster his forces. The first premier denied this.

The dreaded Maoist group, whose brutal 1975-79 rule resulted in the deaths of about one million people, has appeared to be disintegrating in recent months with the defection of key leaders and their soldiers.

Hun Sen was a fighter in Khmer Rouge-led forces in the 1970s before bolting to re-emerge as foreign minister and then prime minister after a 1978 Vietnamese invasion that toppled Cambodia's Maoist regime.
Shelling and small arms fire in Phnom Penh began before dawn on Sunday and continued sporadically through the day, spreading into the heart of Phnom Penh.
Among the casualties was a 38-year-old Japanese man who died after a rocket hit his house, a Foreign Ministry official in Tokyo said.
An official at one city hospital said medical supplies would start running out if fighting continued much longer.
Ranariddh's FUNCINPEC party headquarters and the French embassy next door were both heavily damaged by shellfire, officials said. No one was injured at the embassy.

Ranariddh's father, King Norodom Sihanouk, who has been undergoing medical treatment in Beijing, called on both sides to stop fighting and summoned the feuding co-premiers to the Chinese capital to hammer out a solution.
